results.headline: Harry and Pat and Kay and Richard in 1949

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Married Life

results.summary_short: “Married Life,” a period comedy of manners merged with a suspenseful psychological thriller, aspires to be a hybrid of the sort that Alfred Hitchcock polished to perfection.

results.headline: Love May Not Be All You Need After All

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of J'entends plus la guitare

results.summary_short: “J’Entends Plus la Guitare,” a film by Philippe Garrel, is a fugue composed in a key of philosophical melancholy.

results.headline: A Scream

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of College Road Trip

results.summary_short: Eyes popping and mouths agape, Martin Lawrence and Raven-Symoné mug their way through “College Road Trip” as if it were a silent movie.

results.headline: Human Civilization: The Prequel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10,000 B.C.

results.summary_short: It’s best not to think too hard about anything in “10,000 BC,” a sublimely dunderheaded excursion into human prehistory.

results.headline: Can a Screwball Fable Have an Eye for Detail and a Heart for Fun? Discuss
results.display_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day

results.summary_short: Acting, of course, has something to do with it. But the charm that emanates from Amy Adams like a perfume in “Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day” is also a natural gift.

results.headline: Tunneling Thieves Strike a Lode of Loot (and Valuable Smut)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bank Job

results.summary_short: The workmanlike title “The Bank Job” is a nice fit for this wham-bam caper flick.

results.headline: Ever Upward, No Matter What

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blindsight

results.summary_short: Featuring exceptional people doing extraordinary things, “Blindsight” is one of those documentaries with the power to make you re-examine your entire life.

results.headline: A Haunting Enigma of Violence and Chaos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jar City

results.summary_short: The picture of Iceland that emerges in Baltasar Kormákur’s “Jar City” is vivid and powerful but not something the country’s tourist board would be likely to endorse.

results.headline: Three Kinds of Emotional Baggage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vivere

results.summary_short: Three women converge on the road to self-awareness in “Vivere,” a moody drama from the German director Angelina Maccarone.

results.headline: In the Heart of Texas, a Greenbelt’s Inconvenient Truth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unforeseen

results.summary_short: “The Unforeseen” explores the rights of man, the death of nature, the water below, the air above and all that going, going, gone green in between.

results.headline: Cursed With a Face Only a Sow Could Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Penelope

results.summary_short: “Cinderella” meets “The Ugly Duckling” in “Penelope,” a muddled, charm-free fairy tale whose title character is a rich girl born with the snout of a pig.

results.headline: Fathers and Sons in Gloom Above Rio’s Sunny Beaches

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of City of Men

results.summary_short: “City of Men” is a rootin’-tootin’ gangster movie shot in the notoriously lawless shantytowns overlooking the beaches of Rio de Janeiro.

results.headline: Exploitation’s Wheel Spins in London

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's a Free World...

results.summary_short: It’s a free world, Ken Loach asserts in his latest film with well-practiced disgust and unfortunately little hope.

results.headline: Semi-Animated History of an Animated Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chicago 10

results.summary_short: “Chicago 10,” Brett Morgen’s semi-animated, semi-documentary attempt to make the ’60s cool for a new generation of kids, does the opposite.

results.headline: Brooding on the Bayou

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Chenier

results.summary_short: Men are men, and women are no end of sorry in “Little Chenier,” a steamy saga of jealousy and revenge set on a waterlogged spit of Louisiana land.

results.headline: Open Country for Women of a Certain Age

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bonneville

results.summary_short: Except for Jessica Lange’s silent, expressive close-ups, the women’s journey in “Bonneville” is aesthetically and dramatically unremarkable.

results.headline: From Ground Zero to Boston

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond Belief

results.summary_short: This documentary feature follows 9/11 widows from suburban Boston, as they try to raise money to help war widows in Afghanistan.

results.headline: A Goofball’s Quest: Slam Dunk for Survival

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Semi-Pro

results.summary_short: Like many of Will Ferrell’s recent films, “Semi-Pro” finds the sweet spot between sports melodrama and parody, and hammers it for 90 diverting minutes.

results.headline: Rival Sisters Duke It Out for the Passion of a King

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Boleyn Girl

results.summary_short: More slog than romp, “The Other Boleyn Girl” tells the salacious story of two hot blue bloods who ran amok and partly unclothed in the court of Henry VIII.

results.headline: Two Siblings Stuck in a Junkyard World, Struggling to Survive and Dream

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chop Shop

results.summary_short: “Chop Shop” is concerned principally with the kind of hard, marginal labor that more comfortable city dwellers rarely notice.
